lines.text: This frigging game is ruining my life.
[just before the football match]
Where do I stand for a corner kick?
At the far post, facing the ball.
lines.character: Capt. John Colby - The Players: England

lines.text: Thanks. For a while there I thought you were keeping it a secret.
What's the verdict on Williams?
lines.character: Capt. John Colby - The Players: England

lines.text: A regrettable mistake.
lines.character: Major Karl Von Steiner - The Germans

lines.text: The whole bloody war's a regrettable mistake.
lines.character: Capt. John Colby - The Players: England

lines.text: I agree.
lines.character: Major Karl Von Steiner - The Germans

lines.text: We will win?
We should. We are very strong, but... players can get injured. The referee can make mistakes.
lines.character: Major Karl Von Steiner - The Germans

lines.text:
[knowingly]
Oh, this referee is very good. He will make no mistakes.
We can't do that. I have given my word.
lines.character: Major Karl Von Steiner - The Germans

lines.text: Karl, we cannot afford to take a chance. We must win.
[Hatch has been told he has to return to the prison camp]
What am I supposed to do, break back into the camp?
No. You get captured.
Get captured. All right, suppose I get captured? And then they send me to the wrong prisoner camp. What about that?
No, no.
Now, what about that?

[tsks and shakes his head]
The Germans will take you to the same place again to show the other prisoners you are not a success.
[the Germans have scored their first goal]
And listen to that applause!
[the lead commentator turns on an electronic 'canned applause' device, turning it up to maximum]
The crowd is going wild!
[the camera pans through the audience, showing they're completely silent]

[chanting]
Victoire! Victoire!

[Hatch has asked how she feels about sheltering him]
How do I feel? I feel responsible. Hopeful. When I get word that someone I sheltered is safe, then I'm happy. I can forget them. But when I hear that they've been caught or killed, then I remember everything. I remember their face, their voices, what they said about their parents, their child, their pets, and I mourn for them. I don't want to mourn for you.
Well, you're safe with me, Renée.
How?
Well, I'm, uh... an orphan, a bastard. I have no parents, no money, no wife, no children. I don't even have a pet. Anything I say in my sleep to the contrary can't be held against me.
[Renée smiles]
[Eastern European players have been brought from labor camps to play on the team]
They're all great players.
lines.character: Capt. John Colby - The Players: England

lines.text: They WERE.
[the camera focuses on the five men, frail and starved, dressed in filthy rags]

[angrily]
You are a naive fool, Colby. Insisting on great players? Von Steiner has sent you five skeletons. Guarantees that you'll turn up in Paris for his propaganda victory.
Colonel, I...
lines.character: Capt. John Colby - The Players: England

lines.text: The Germans are doing their job very well. London knows. We heard it on the news. It's in all the papers. They're calling it another German lie. London is saying that no British officer would ever be involved in such a game.
London is saying, Colonel? What about those poor bastards there? Do we send them back to the labor camps?
lines.character: Capt. John Colby - The Players: England

lines.text: That's a very good question, Colby.
